questionList.questionText: A 68-year-old man comes to the office due to "strange visions."  He lives alone and has not seen a doctor in 30 years.  The patient says, "I started seeing people passing through my peripheral vision in the evenings about 2 months ago.  What's weird is that my closest neighbors are 2 miles away, and I rarely have visitors."  The patient is not forgetful and still drives, goes grocery shopping, prepares meals, and takes care of chores around the house.  He says his energy is "not what it used to be," and he has lost his balance a few times but has not fallen.  The patient was told to see a doctor for his "shaky hands" several years ago but never sought an evaluation.  Temperature is 37.1 C (98.8 F), blood pressure is 138/89 mm Hg, pulse is 78/min, and respirations are 14/min.  There are decreased facial expression and reduced eye blinking.  He has a tremor at rest that is most prominent in the right hand.  There is resistance to passive movement in all limbs that is worse on the right.  Gait is steady but slow.  The patient has a score of 29/30 (normal: ≥26) on the Montreal Cognitive Assessment.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Parkinson disease vs dementia with Lewy bodies

Parkinson disease

DLB

Dementia

  • Late: >1 year after parkinsonism onset
  • Eventually develops in most patients (>10 years)
  • Early: <1 year of parkinsonism onset
  • Essential to diagnosis

Parkinsonism*

  • Prominent, typically asymmetric
  • 100% at dementia diagnosis
  • Usually mild (<50% at diagnosis), more symmetric

Visual
hallucinations

  • Usually mild in untreated disease
  • Often late sign, worsen with dopaminergic drugs
  • Usually well-formed & detailed
  • Prominent early sign

*Bradykinesia, rest tremor, rigidity & postural instability.

DLB = dementia with Lewy bodies.

Hallucinations in the setting of parkinsonism (ie, bradykinesia, tremor, rigidity, postural instability) can occur with both Parkinson disease (PD) and dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB), which share neuropathologic findings (ie, alpha-synuclein inclusions/Lewy bodies).

Some characteristics may help distinguish the 2 conditions:

  • The major clinical distinction is the timing of dementia relative to parkinsonism. Dementia occurring >1 year after parkinsonism onset is classified as PD, whereas dementia preceding or starting <1 year from parkinsonism onset denotes DLB.

  • Characteristics of hallucinations can also be helpful.  DLB is characterized by well-formed visual hallucinations (eg, detailed images of people/small animals) that occur early in the disease; similar hallucinations are sometimes seen with PD, but they are classically related to drug (eg, dopaminergic) therapy and occur later in the disease.  However, minor hallucinations (uncommon in DLB) occur in approximately 40% of patients with untreated PD and can be a premotor symptom; in contrast to well-formed visual hallucinations, minor hallucinations are characterized as sensations of presence (ie, someone nearby) and/or passage (ie, someone passing through peripheral vision), as seen in this patient.

  • Other features:  Findings more characteristic of PD include asymmetric parkinsonism, more gradual progression, earlier onset, and increased levodopa responsiveness (vs DLB).

This patient does not have dementia (eg, normal cognitive assessment, intact activities of daily living such as driving and shopping) despite longstanding parkinsonism (eg, tremor starting years ago); he also has minor hallucinations of passage.  These features make PD more likely than DLB (Choice B).

(Choice A)  Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease can cause extrapyramidal signs (eg, bradykinesia, rigidity) and visual hallucinations.  However, neuromotor manifestations typically include myoclonus, cerebellar signs (eg, ataxia), and/or upper motor neuron findings.  Moreover, patients have rapidly progressive dementia with decline to death usually occurring within one year of disease onset.

(Choice C)  Although major depressive disorder with psychotic features frequently involves hallucinations, the psychotic symptoms typically have depressive themes (eg, guilt, worthlessness), unlike the passage/presence hallucinations seen with untreated PD.  In addition, this patient has only one clear symptom of depression (low energy), and depression would not explain parkinsonism.

(Choice D)  Normal pressure hydrocephalus is associated with urinary incontinence, gait disorder, and cognitive decline ("wet, wobbly, wacky").  Hallucinations and parkinsonism are not characteristic.

Educational objective:
Parkinson disease (PD) and dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB) both cause parkinsonism and dementia but can be distinguished by timing (PD: dementia >1 year after parkinsonism; DLB: dementia prior to or <1 year after parkinsonism).  Well-formed hallucinations are more common in DLB (and can occur in PD patients receiving dopaminergic therapy), but minor hallucinations (presence/passage) can be seen even in untreated PD.

questionList.questionText: A 32-year-old woman with bipolar disorder comes to the office for follow-up.  The patient was diagnosed and treated for a manic episode at age 29 and has been stable on a combination of lithium and risperidone.  Her mood has been "fine" overall, but she has been stressed about work.  After a staff meeting a few weeks ago, her supervisor said she appeared angry because she was repeatedly frowning while others were presenting.  Since then, the patient has been increasingly self-conscious and has started eating lunch alone at her desk.  Temperature is 37.0 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 132/78 mm Hg, pulse is 72/min, and respirations are 14/min.  Physical examination is unremarkable except for occasional grimacing and slow inversion and tapping movements of her right foot.  Lithium level is 0.9 mEq/L (normal: 0.6-1.2).  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in pharmacological management?
questionList.explanationText:
Tardive dyskinesia

Clinical features

  • Abnormal involuntary movements due to prolonged use of antipsychotics or metoclopramide
  • Orofacial dyskinesia (tongue protrusion, lip smacking, grimacing)
  • Limb dyskinesia (dystonic postures, foot tapping, chorea)
  • Trunk dyskinesia (rocking, thrusting, shoulder shrugging)
  • Greater risk with first-generation antipsychotics

Management

  • Discontinue causative medication if feasible
  • Switch to second-generation antipsychotic (quetiapine, clozapine) if continued antipsychotic is required
  • Treat with valbenazine or deutetrabenazine

This patient's facial grimacing combined with foot tapping and inversion movements are most likely signs of tardive dyskinesia (TD) caused by exposure to risperidone, a second-generation antipsychotic (SGA) used in the treatment of bipolar and psychotic disorders.  Although most commonly associated with first-generation antipsychotics and antiemetic metoclopramide, TD may also occur with some SGAs.  The risk of TD varies significantly within the SGA class; risperidone is among the highest-risk SGAs whereas clozapine and quetiapine are among the lowest-risk SGAs.

Patients receiving maintenance antipsychotic medication should be assessed for TD at regular intervals and the causative medication tapered and discontinued if feasible.  This patient has been stable (ie, no recurrent mood episodes for 3 years) and may not require maintenance risperidone because lithium may adequately control her symptoms.  Therefore, a gradual taper and discontinuation of risperidone is the most appropriate initial management.  When antipsychotic dose reduction or discontinuation is not feasible, treatment options include switching to a lower-risk agent (eg, clozapine) or treatment with a vesicular monoamine transporter 2 inhibitor (eg, valbenazine, deutetrabenazine).

(Choice A)  Anticholinergic drugs (eg, benztropine) are ineffective and may worsen TD.  Benztropine is indicated in the treatment of acute dystonia.

(Choice B)  Propranolol has been used in the treatment of akathisia, a type of extrapyramidal symptom characterized by inner restlessness and inability to sit still.  It is ineffective in treating TD.

(Choice C)  Lithium is not the causative agent of this patient's TD and should be maintained.  Switching to valproic acid would risk destabilizing the patient.

(Choice D)  Continued exposure to risperidone would likely exacerbate the patient's TD.

(Choice E)  This patient is not in a major depressive episode.  Adding an antidepressant (eg, fluoxetine) may have destabilizing effects in a bipolar patient and would not treat TD.

Educational objective:
Tardive dyskinesia is characterized by abnormal involuntary movements of the face, lips, tongue, trunk, or extremities that develop as a result of prolonged exposure to antipsychotic medication.  If feasible, the causative medication should be tapered and discontinued.

questionList.questionText: A 35-year-old man comes to the office due to persistent fatigue and insomnia for the past 3 weeks.  The patient was fired from his job as an insurance salesman a month ago due to poor sales and has since felt increasingly tired.  He has no difficulty falling asleep but, "for no reason," awakens at 4 AM most nights.  The patient's wife has told him he snores occasionally, although he has not awakened short of breath.  He says, "I liked going to the gym with my friends, but now I just don't want to anymore.  I'm at home a lot now, but I don't have the energy to play with my kids."  The patient feels pressured to look for new job opportunities but is so unfocused that he has not been able to complete any applications.  Medical history is significant for hypertension treated with enalapril.  Weight is 81 kg (178.6 lb) and height is 180.3 cm (5 ft 11 in).  Vital signs are within normal limits.  Physical examination and laboratory studies show no abnormalities.  The patient moves slowly and appears withdrawn.  Polysomnography is recommended to assess for sleep abnormalities.  This patient is most likely to have which of the following findings?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient's 3-week history of low energy, sleep disturbance, decreased interest, and impaired concentration, as well as the finding of psychomotor slowing on mental status examination, is consistent with major depressive disorder (MDD).  Sleep abnormalities are a core symptom of depression and may include difficulty falling asleep, interrupted sleep, early morning awakening, and hypersomnia.

A characteristic polysomnographic finding in MDD is decreased REM sleep latency (the time from sleep onset until the start of the first REM sleep period), which is considered a biomarker for depression.  Other sleep findings in depressed patients include decreased slow-wave sleep and increased REM sleep duration and density, as well as disruptions in sleep continuity.  Sleep disturbances in MDD typically return to normal with antidepressant treatment.

(Choice B)  Increased periodic limb movements during sleep (ie, involuntary jerking movements of the legs) may cause nighttime arousals, which typically lead to excessive daytime somnolence.  Periodic limb movement disorder would not explain this patient's marked depressive symptoms.

(Choice C)  Slow-wave sleep (also known as deep sleep) is decreased, not increased, in MDD.

(Choice D)  Loss of normal REM sleep atonia is a feature of REM sleep behavior disorder, a parasomnia characterized by dream-enactment behaviors.

(Choice E)  Sleep-related hypoventilation and apneas on polysomnography are characteristic of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).  These patients commonly have a history of observed breathing pauses, snoring, and gasping for air, as well as excessive daytime sleeping rather than early morning awakening.  Although this patient has some risk factors for OSA (eg, male, hypertension, snoring), he has a normal BMI and no evidence of interrupted breathing.  MDD is a better explanation for his 3-week history of symptoms.

Educational objective:
Sleep disturbance is a core symptom of depression.  Polysomnographic findings in major depressive disorder include decreased REM latency and slow-wave sleep, as well as increased REM sleep duration and REM sleep density.

questionList.questionText: A 23-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her roommate due to bizarre behavior.  The roommate reports that, over the past few days, the patient has become increasingly paranoid.  She stays up almost all night and believes the apartment is bugged.  The roommate became alarmed when the patient did not go to work yesterday and started speaking in a whisper.  When interviewed, the patient does not respond verbally to questions but calmly writes on a piece of paper, "I've been warned not to say anything."  Her parents are contacted and report a history of depression treated with bupropion.  They have never observed the behavior their daughter is exhibiting.  The parents report that the patient drinks alcohol socially but do not believe she uses illicit drugs.  Vital signs and physical examination are unremarkable.  Family history is significant for bipolar disorder in a maternal uncle.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient demonstrates signs of new-onset acute psychosis (eg, delusions, possible hallucinations) of unclear etiology.  Major depressive or manic episode with psychotic features should be considered given the patient's history of depression and family history of bipolar disorder.  However, before making a primary psychiatric diagnosis, substance-induced and other medical causes should be ruled out.

The basic medical workup for new-onset psychosis commonly includes complete physical and mental status examinations, metabolic panel, complete blood cell count, and urine toxicology screen.  It may also include tests for syphilis, HIV, vitamin B12 level, thyroid function, and antinuclear antibodies, as well as neuroimaging depending on specific findings and risk factors.  In a young patient with no significant medical history and normal physical examination results, obtaining a urine toxicology screen is the most appropriate next step in evaluation (eg, a screen positive for cocaine or amphetamine suggests a stimulant-induced psychosis).  The parents' report cannot be relied on to rule out illicit or prescription drug use.

(Choice A)  Mood stabilizers (eg, lithium, valproate) are used in the treatment of bipolar disorder, which may present with psychotic features.  However, the diagnosis of bipolar disorder requires evidence of at least 1 manic episode (eg, elevated or irritable mood, increased energy, flight of ideas, agitation, pressured speech), which is lacking in this patient.

(Choice B)  An antipsychotic medication would be appropriate for the treatment of primary mood disorder with psychotic features and/or to calm a severely agitated psychotic patient.  However, the etiology of this patient's psychosis is unclear, and she is currently calm and cooperative.

(Choice C)  Like all antidepressants, bupropion may contribute to a manic presentation, but this is not known to correlate with bupropion levels.

(Choice D)  In the absence of focal neurologic findings, neuroimaging is not indicated.

Educational objective:
Substance-induced psychosis should be considered in the differential diagnosis of all patients who come to the emergency department with acute psychosis.  Standard workup of new-onset psychosis includes obtaining a urine toxicology screen.

questionList.questionText: A 72-year-old man with a history of chronic pain and unknown psychiatric history comes for an initial visit due to diminished energy and anxiety for the past 3 months.  He appears very sad and moves slowly.  He has felt terrible since his wife died unexpectedly from a brain aneurysm 4 months ago and is filled with guilt because he did not get her to the hospital sooner.  Since her death, the patient has suffered from disturbed sleep and is unable to focus on his favorite activities, including coin collecting and fishing.  He drinks a bottle of wine nightly to fall asleep and isolates himself from others because he does not feel like socializing anymore.  The patient feels hopeless and wants to end his life, saying, "I cannot carry on without her."  He has contemplated hanging himself and recently drove by a hardware store with thoughts of buying a rope, but ultimately did not.  The patient is advised to enter a psychiatric hospital.  However, he refuses and says, "I promise to try any help you could offer me as an outpatient."  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Management of suicidality

Management

Imminent risk of suicide (voiced intent, high number of unmanaged risk factors, collateral concerns raised)

  • Ensure safety: hospitalize immediately (involuntary if necessary) & start 1:1 for constant observation
  • Remove personal belongings & objects in room that may present self-harm risk
  • Security may be required to hold against will
 

Nonimminent risk of suicide (no intent, strong social supports available, outpatient follow-up plan is reasonable)

  • Create safety plan (eg, coping skills, social supports, crisis numbers)
  • Ensure close follow-up (eg, psychiatry, therapy, intensive outpatient program)
  • Plan to address modifiable risk factors (eg, depression, psychosis, substance use, pain)
  • Ensure family or friends available to support patient
  • Remove access to potential means (eg, secure firearms & medications)

This patient has symptoms consistent with major depression and reports suicidal ideation with a specific method.  His aborted trip to the hardware store to buy a rope indicates that the patient recently had some intent and an organized plan for self-harm (rehearsing a plan is not uncommon prior to suicide attempts).  His depressive symptoms appear to be worsening, and he has several other major risk factors for suicide that can be remembered by using the mnemonic SAD PERSONS: old age, male gender, alcohol abuse, chronic pain, and lack of support/significant other.  His anxiety, hopelessness, and disturbed sleep patterns are additional clinical risk factors.

Given this high level of suicide risk, it is necessary to admit the patient to a psychiatric unit (involuntarily if necessary) to ensure his safety as the first step in care.  Significant concern about the patient's immediate safety overrides any "promises" that he may make about agreeing to outpatient treatment, especially when there is no established therapeutic alliance or relationship between patient and physician.

(Choices B and G)  Outpatient psychotherapy, with or without antidepressant treatment, would not adequately address the imminent safety concerns in this patient.  His depressive symptoms (ie, suicidality and marked functional impairment) are more severe than those seen in normal bereavement.

(Choice C)  There is little evidence that a "no-harm" contract (a patient promise not to harm self when feeling suicidal) is effective in reducing suicide.

(Choice D)  Hypothyroidism, which can also present with sad mood, diminished energy, slow movement, and poor concentration, can be assessed with serum TSH testing.  However, this patient's high suicide risk precludes outpatient management.

(Choice E)  Antidepressants can take weeks to become fully effective and alone would not adequately address the patient's suicide risk.  It is also inappropriate to give family members responsibility for monitoring the patient's safety.

(Choice F)  Day programs are outpatient programs.  This patient would remain at risk, particularly in the evenings when alcohol intoxication and loneliness could predispose him to a higher risk of suicide.  His level of suicide risk requires treatment in an inpatient (ie, locked unit) setting.

Educational objective:
Active suicidality is associated with intent and plan for self-harm.  The first step in the care of patients with active suicidality is to ensure their safety by admitting them to a psychiatric unit (involuntarily, if necessary).

questionList.explanationText:
Major depressive disorder vs seasonal affective disorder*

MDD

SAD

Clinical features

  • Single or recurrent major depressive episodes (≥2 weeks of ≥5 of depression + SIG‑E‑CAPS)
  • No seasonal pattern
  • Recurrent major depressive episodes
  • ≥2-year pattern of seasonal recurrence & remission (eg, winter onset–spring remission)
  • No nonseasonal depressive episodes
  • Lifetime seasonal >>> nonseasonal depressive episodes

Management

  • Antidepressant (eg, SSRI)
  • Psychotherapy (CBT)
  • Combined therapy
  • Antidepressant (eg, SSRI) + light therapy
  • Psychotherapy (CBT)
  • Behavioral (eg, outdoor walks, aerobic exercise, sleep hygiene)

*Seasonal affective disorder = major depressive disorder with seasonal pattern.

CBT = cognitive-behavioral therapy; MDD = major depressive disorder; SAD = seasonal affective disorder; SIG‑E‑CAPS = Sleep, Interest, Guilt, Energy, Concentration, Appetite, Psychomotor changes, Suicidality; SSRI = selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor.

This patient's history of recurrent major depressive episodes with onset in the fall and remission in the spring is characteristic of major depressive disorder with seasonal pattern (also known as seasonal affective disorder [SAD]).  SAD with fall-winter onset and spring-summer remission is the most common type of seasonal depression.  It is generally characterized by atypical features of depression such as increased sleep, increased appetite, carbohydrate craving, and weight gain.

First-line treatment consists of antidepressant and bright light therapy.  This patient has had a partial response to antidepressant therapy and would benefit from the addition of light therapy.  Bright light therapy is typically administered with a 10,000-lux light box shortly after the patient awakens.  Most patients experience clinical improvement in 1-4 weeks and continue treatment through the fall or winter until spontaneous remission of symptoms in the spring or summer.  Light therapy alone is also a reasonable first option for patients with mild to moderate SAD.

(Choices A and F)  Bupropion can be used to augment a partially effective antidepressant regimen or as monotherapy in the treatment of SAD.  However, pharmacologic augmentation or changing to an alternate medication (eg, venlafaxine) should not be considered until the patient reaches an optimal dose of the current antidepressant to avoid polypharmacy and loss of therapeutic potential.

(Choice B)  Given the severity of this patient's symptoms, more regular follow-up intervals are needed.  However, she has been taking the initial dose of fluoxetine long enough to determine its response; making no changes to her treatment at this time unnecessarily prolongs her symptoms.  A suitable alternative would be to increase the fluoxetine dose.

(Choices C and E)  A symptom diary is helpful for timing a patient's mood symptoms when a diagnosis of premenstrual dysphoric disorder is being considered, and combined oral contraceptive pills can be used to manage premenstrual syndrome.  However, this patient's depressed mood persists for months and is unrelated to menses, making a major depressive disorder more likely.

Educational objective:
Major depressive disorder with seasonal pattern (seasonal affective disorder) is characterized by seasonal onset and remission (most commonly fall-winter onset and spring-summer remission).  Treatment consists of bright light therapy alone or with an antidepressant.

questionList.questionText: A 27-year-old woman comes to the office due to headaches and neck and back pain.  She has been coping with pain symptoms for several years but notes that they have increased since she was recently let go from her job as an administrative assistant.  The patient worries about finding another job but says, "Most days I am just too tired to even look for work."  She is also concerned about gaining weight but has no motivation to go to the gym or leave the house.  The patient has been to the office twice in the past year for similar symptoms and is worried that something is wrong.  At her last visit 4 months ago, laboratory testing, including a basic chemistry panel, thyroid function tests, and complete blood count, were within normal range.  The patient says, "I doubt that anything will ever improve for me."  Medications include ibuprofen for pain as needed.  The patient drinks 1 or 2 glasses of wine 3 times a week.  She has increased her use of marijuana to 3 or 4 times a week at bedtime to help her relax and fall asleep and has started smoking cigarettes after a 2-year abstinence.  Family history includes hypertension and colon cancer in her father and hypothyroidism and anxiety in her mother.  Vital signs and physical examination are normal except for a 2.27-kg (5-lb) weight gain since her last visit.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient has several findings concerning for depression, including hopelessness (doubts that anything will improve), amotivation, low energy, and weight gain.  Patients with depression frequently have a somatic presentation (eg, headaches, neck and back pain) and may have difficulty describing their emotions.  Further assessment of depression, including a careful screen for suicidal ideation, is the most appropriate next step in this patient's evaluation, particularly given her multiple risk factors for suicide (eg, chronic pain, recent job loss, self-medication with substances, isolation).

Inquiring about suicidality allows for the determination of an appropriate and safe treatment setting (eg, hospitalization if the patient is actively suicidal).  This patient should be asked if she has wished for death or has thought of killing herself.  If the answer is "yes," additional questions should be asked regarding methods, plan, and intent to act on a plan.

(Choices A, B, and C)  Although exploring the relationship of substance use and stress to the patient's symptoms and performing a more detailed pain assessment are components of a comprehensive evaluation, inquiring about suicidal thoughts takes precedence.

(Choice E)  In light of this patient's recent laboratory results and the absence of new physical findings, repeat laboratory testing is unlikely to be helpful.  Her weight gain is likely due to depression and lack of exercise rather than thyroid disease.

(Choice F)  Reassurance that serious illness has been ruled out with regular follow-up office visits is an appropriate intervention for somatic symptom disorder.  However, this would not substitute for evaluation of suicidality in this patient with findings concerning for depression.

Educational objective:
In the primary care setting, patients with depression often have somatic symptoms.  Any patient who reports feeling hopeless, even if the initial symptoms are somatic, should be screened for suicidal ideation.

questionList.questionText: A 31-year-old woman comes to the office due to fatigue and weight gain.  She has felt tired over the past 2 months and is upset that she has been craving junk food and has gained 8 pounds.  She says, "I have been under some stress at work lately, and I guess I've been eating and sleeping more as a way to cope and escape.  I know I've gained weight but I feel slow—like my legs are in cement blocks."  The patient sleeps 10-12 hours a day but still feels tired throughout the day.  She is feeling "down" and stopped socializing with friends "because I feel that I look awful and don't want to be around anybody."  However, she was able to enjoy a recent family reunion and was excited to meet her newborn nephew for the first time.  The patient has no medical or psychiatric history.  She has 1-2 glasses of wine 3 times a week and uses cannabis approximately once a month.  Physical examination is normal.  On mental status examination the patient appears sad and tired but is able to smile when appropriate.  Laboratory evaluation, including complete blood count and thyroid function tests, is within normal range.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient's 2-month history of depressed mood (eg, feeling "down"), social isolation (loss of interest), fatigue (loss of energy), hypersomnia, leaden paralysis ("my legs are in cement blocks"), and weight gain is most consistent with the atypical subtype of major depressive disorder (MDD).

A core feature of atypical depression is mood reactivity (ie, positive responsiveness to pleasant events); other characteristic features include increased appetite or weight gain, hypersomnia, leaden paralysis (heavy feeling in limbs), and hypersensitivity to rejection.  This patient's ability to enjoy the family reunion and smile during the interview are examples of the mood reactivity characteristic of the atypical subtype.

In contrast, the melancholic subtype of MDD is characterized by weight loss, insomnia, and pervasive anhedonia with an inability to respond to positive events.

(Choices A and C)  MDD can be differentiated from adjustment disorder and a normal stress response by the number and severity of symptoms and the degree of functional impairment.  Adjustment disorder involves depressive symptoms developing within 3 months of a stressor with resultant functional impairment but insufficient number and severity of symptoms to meet the criteria for MDD.  A normal stress response is not excessive or out of proportion to the severity of the stressor and does not cause functional impairment.

(Choice D)  Persistent depressive disorder (dysthymia) requires a chronically depressed mood for ≥2 years.

(Choice E)  The extent of this patient's alcohol and cannabis use is unlikely to be causing her symptom severity and impairment.

Educational objective:
Atypical features of major depressive disorder include hypersomnia, hyperphagia, heavy feelings in limbs, hypersensitivity to rejection, and mood reactivity (ability to respond to positive events).

questionList.questionText: A 28-year-old woman is brought to the hospital by her family due to depressed mood, disorganized behavior, and hearing voices.  Over the past 2 months, the patient has developed worsening auditory hallucinations and now fears that her family has been replaced by imposters.  She is afraid to leave the house, stays in bed most of the day, and is unable to care for herself.  The patient's psychiatric history is significant for 4 previous hospitalizations for depressive and psychotic symptoms over the past 8 years.  During the first hospitalization, she was suicidal and heard voices.  During her most recent hospitalization a year ago, she was severely depressed and preoccupied with paranoid delusions and auditory hallucinations.  Between hospitalizations, the patient has had rare month-long periods during which she is not depressed but continues to hear voices.  On mental status examination, she makes poor eye contact.  Her mood is depressed, but she has no suicidal ideation.  She is convinced that her mother is an imposter trying to harm her.  The patient does not use alcohol or illicit drugs.  Physical examination is unremarkable.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Schizoaffective disorder

DSM-5 criteria

  • Major depressive or manic episode concurrent with symptoms of schizophrenia
  • Lifetime history of delusions or hallucinations for ≥2 weeks in the absence of major depressive or manic episode
  • Mood episodes are prominent & recur throughout illness
  • Not due to substances or another medical condition

Differential diagnosis

  • Major depressive or bipolar disorder with psychotic features:  Psychotic symptoms occur exclusively during mood episodes
  • Schizophrenia:  Mood symptoms may be present for relatively brief periods

The course of this patient's illness is consistent with a diagnosis of schizoaffective disorder, which requires the following:

  • Major mood (depressive or manic) episodes concurrent with symptoms of schizophrenia (≥2 of the following for ≥6 months:  delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, grossly disorganized behavior, negative symptoms)
  • Delusions or hallucinations for ≥2 weeks in the absence of a major mood episode (depressive or manic)

This patient has an 8-year history of psychotic symptoms with concurrent depressive symptoms but also has month-long periods during which psychosis persisted in the absence of mood symptoms (eg, hearing voices even when not depressed).  This meets the criteria for schizoaffective disorder, depressive type.

Differentiating schizoaffective disorder from bipolar disorder, major depression with psychotic features, and schizophrenia requires determining the temporal relationship of psychotic symptoms to mood symptoms.  In bipolar disorder and major depression with psychotic features, psychotic symptoms occur exclusively during manic or depressive episodes (ie, when the patient's mood is stable, there are no psychotic symptoms).  In schizophrenia, if mood symptoms occur, they are present for a small portion of the illness.

(Choice A)  The diagnosis of bipolar I disorder requires ≥1 manic episodes, and psychotic symptoms, if present, occur exclusively during mood episodes.  There is no evidence of manic symptoms in this patient.

(Choice B)  In delusional disorder, other symptoms of psychosis (eg, hallucinations, disorganized speech, disorganized behavior) are not present.  In addition, delusional disorder would not explain this patient's current and previous history of depression.

(Choice C)  The persistence of hallucinations for ≥2 weeks in the absence of a major depressive episode rules out major depressive disorder with psychotic features.

(Choices E and F)  Schizophrenia and schizophreniform disorder are characterized by psychotic symptoms.  If mood symptoms occur, they are present for only a small portion of the illness.  Duration of psychotic illness differentiates schizophreniform disorder (>1 month and <6 months) from schizophrenia (≥6 months).

Educational objective:
Schizoaffective disorder is diagnosed when major depressive or manic episodes co-occur with psychotic symptoms in a patient with a history of persistent psychosis for ≥2 weeks in the absence of mood symptoms.

questionList.questionText: A 73-year-old man with bipolar disorder is brought to the emergency department by his daughter, who has been visiting him for several days.  She reports that "he's not himself."  The patient has become increasingly confused, which is not typical for him.  He has bilateral hand tremors, has difficulty walking straight, and has vomited over the past few days.  Two weeks ago, he saw his new primary care physician, who added hydrochlorothiazide to the patient's medication regimen.  The patient has been psychiatrically stable for many years and has been seeing a psychiatrist, who has prescribed mood stabilizers and antipsychotics.  He has no history of alcohol or substance use disorders.  His daughter does not know which psychiatric medications he takes.  Temperature is 37.2 C (99 F), blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg, pulse is 65/min, and respirations are 16/min.  The patient's pulse oximetry shows 93% on room air.  He is disoriented and ataxic.  As he is being assessed, he has a generalized seizure that lasts 2-3 minutes.  Which of the following medications is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questionList.explanationText:
Lithium toxicity

Etiology

Acute toxicity

  • Intentional overdose

Chronic toxicity

  • Decreased renal perfusion (↓ lithium clearance)
    • Dehydration
    • Thiazide diuretics, NSAIDs, ACE inhibitors

Clinical features

Acute toxicity

  • Gastrointestinal: nausea, vomiting, diarrhea
  • Late neurologic sequelae

Chronic toxicity (neurologic)

  • Lethargy, confusion, agitation
  • Ataxia, tremor/fasciculations, seizure

Treatment

  • Intravenous hydration
  • Hemodialysis (severe cases)

NSAID = nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug.

This patient is exhibiting signs and symptoms of lithium toxicity.  These may include new onset of severe gastrointestinal symptoms, confusion, ataxia, tremor, and other signs of neuromuscular irritability such as fasciculations and seizures.  This patient was previously stable on his psychiatric medications; therefore, the recent addition of hydrochlorothiazide is likely responsible for increasing his lithium serum level.  Thiazide diuretics can cause a decrease in the renal clearance of lithium and lead to lithium toxicity.  The risk of lithium toxicity is higher in patients with dehydration from any cause (eg, vomiting, diarrhea, fever, diuresis) and in elderly patients due to a lower glomerular filtration rate and reduced volume of distribution.

Other medications that can increase lithium levels include ACE inhibitors, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, tetracyclines, and metronidazole.

(Choices A, B, and E)  Bupropion is a dopamine and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor used as an antidepressant and as an aid for smoking cessation.  The antipsychotics haloperidol and risperidone are dopamine antagonists used to treat psychosis or as adjuncts to mood stabilizers in the treatment of bipolar disorder.  Although bupropion, haloperidol, and risperidone can increase neuromuscular irritability and the risk of seizures, none are typically associated with this patient's other presenting symptoms.

(Choices C and F)  Lamotrigine and valproic acid are anticonvulsants that are also used in the treatment of bipolar disorder.  Lamotrigine is associated with Stevens-Johnson syndrome.  Valproic acid may cause gastrointestinal symptoms, hepatitis, pancreatitis, and hepatic encephalopathy.  Both medications would decrease rather than increase the risk of seizures.

Educational objective:
Concurrent use of thiazide diuretics—as well as ACE inhibitors, tetracyclines, metronidazole, and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs—and lithium can increase serum lithium levels and lead to symptoms of lithium toxicity, including gastrointestinal symptoms, confusion, ataxia, tremor, and seizures.

questionList.questionText: An 85-year-old man comes to the office for a routine health evaluation.  The patient lives independently but is accompanied by his daughter who does his grocery shopping and visits him weekly.  The daughter is concerned that her father seems increasingly withdrawn and forgetful over the past year.  She reports that he does not socialize with his neighborhood friends as much as he used to and calls her less frequently.  "When we do speak, he often seems to forget what I just told him and repeats the same question that I've just answered."  The patient admits that he sometimes forgets names but attributes this to "old age."  He denies any changes in mood, sleep, or appetite.  Medical history includes hypertension and osteoarthritis of the knees.  Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide and ibuprofen.  Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination is unremarkable.  The patient is pleasant and cooperative and speaks loudly.  Montreal Cognitive Assessment score is 26/30.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Age-related hearing loss (presbycusis) is extremely common, affecting more than half of all adults age ≥75.  Some patients may be unaware of their deficits when hearing loss progresses slowly.  Rather than seeking help for hearing loss, these patients may come in or be brought in with increasing social isolation and cognitive difficulties as they avoid engaging in conversations and misunderstand what is being said.

This patient's presentation includes several clues for hearing loss, including withdrawal from his neighborhood friends, fewer telephone calls to his daughter, repeated questions, and loud speaking; his daughter's impression that he forgets what she just told him (whereas he may have misheard or misunderstood what she had said) is likely a further reflection of presbycusis.  Other clues for age-related hearing loss include turning the television or radio volume up and difficulty hearing in a crowd or when background noise is present.  If not addressed, age-related hearing loss can lead to increasing loneliness, depression, cognitive impairment, and functional disability.

The most appropriate next step is to take a careful history of hearing changes and perform a whispered voice test.  Audiometric testing can be used to confirm the diagnosis (if necessary) and direct management (eg, hearing aids, cochlear implants).

(Choice A)  Although depression can also cause social isolation and cognitive impairment, it is typically accompanied by other symptoms, such as changes in mood, sleep, and appetite, which are not present in this case.

(Choice C)  A home geriatric assessment identifies and coordinates planning for older adults with significant medical, psychosocial, and functional disabilities (eg, hip fracture, increased fall risk, depression, cognitive decline, those at risk for high use of health care services).  A simple screen for hearing loss should precede an intensive evaluation in this patient.

(Choices D and F)  An MRI scan of the brain and thyroid function testing would be appropriate in the workup for suspected dementia.  However, this patient's cognitive assessment score is within normal limits; a score ≤24/30 is generally used as a cutoff for significant cognitive impairment.  Forgetting names occasionally is consistent with normal age-related changes.  In addition, the patient has no additional signs or symptoms that suggest neurologic or thyroid dysfunction.

(Choice E)  It would be inappropriate to dismiss the daughter's concerns about her father's social withdrawal and cognitive difficulties without an evaluation for treatable conditions, such as hearing loss.

Educational objective:
Hearing loss in the elderly is common and may present with social isolation and cognitive decline.  Careful history-taking and a whispered voice test should be conducted.  Audiometric testing can help confirm the diagnosis and direct management.

questionList.questionText: A 19-year-old man is brought to the office by his mother due to sad mood and declining grades at college.  Previously a straight-A student, he is now getting Cs and Ds, and his mother worries he will not complete his freshman year.  The patient says, "I feel depressed and hopeless about the future."  He has little interest in his classes, has difficulty concentrating on assignments, and abruptly decided to quit the soccer team.  He refuses to answer any phone calls from his friends and keeps himself isolated at home.  The patient feels that there is little point in living but has no suicidal intent or plan.  He has tried alcohol at parties on 2 occasions but does not use illicit drugs.  There is no history of mania.  There is a family history of untreated depression in his mother and grandmother.  Physical examination and laboratory values are normal.  Major depressive disorder is diagnosed, and treatment is discussed.  The patient is willing to take medication, but his mother is concerned that antidepressants can cause people to become suicidal.  Which of the following is the most appropriate response to the mother?
questionList.explanationText:
In 2007 the US Food and Drug Administration extended its warning that all patients age <25 should be informed about the small risk of becoming suicidal during initial antidepressant treatment.  The warning was based on studies showing a slightly increased risk of suicidal thoughts and behaviors (not completed suicide) among a small group of child and adolescent patients treated with antidepressants compared with placebo (Choice D).

Decisions regarding prescribing antidepressants for adolescents must weigh the risk of antidepressant-related suicidal thoughts and behaviors against the established benefits of antidepressants and the long-term risk of completed suicide in untreated depression.

Although there is ongoing debate about the evidence for a link between antidepressants and suicidality, the consensus among experts and in practice guidelines is that the benefits of antidepressants for moderate to severe depression outweigh the risks.  Antidepressant treatment should not be withheld due to this concern or limited to patients who have failed psychotherapy (Choice A).

Physicians should closely monitor patients for increasing suicidal thoughts and behaviors, especially following initiation of antidepressant treatment.

(Choice B)  Although some antidepressants are avoided as first-line agents due to their adverse side-effect profile, there is no known or clear difference in the risk of suicidal thoughts or behaviors among different classes of antidepressants.  All adolescents started on an antidepressant should be monitored closely.

(Choice C)  The warning is applicable to all patients under age 25 years, not just those under age 18.

Educational objective:
The slightly increased risk of antidepressant-related suicidal thoughts and behaviors in some children and adolescents must be weighed against the efficacy of antidepressants and the risk of completed suicide in depression.  Patients should be carefully monitored for suicidality at the beginning of antidepressant therapy.

questionList.questionText: A 35-year-old woman comes to the office due to poor energy.  She says, "Although I have no energy, I still can't sleep and am up most of the night.  I drag myself to work but barely get anything done because I have no motivation and can hardly concentrate.  I'm a horrible wife and mother.  I don't want to go out anymore or do anything.  All I want to do is hide in my room and get into bed."  The patient has a history of 3 prior episodes of depression beginning at age 18.  She was also hospitalized 3 years ago for aggressive behavior following an arrest for unauthorized use of her company's funds to finance a personal business venture.  At that time, she had excessive energy, slept 2 hours a night, and believed that she had a brilliant idea that would revolutionize the computer industry.  The patient has no history of recreational substance use.  There is a family history of depression in her mother, whose condition responded well to tricyclic antidepressants.  Mental status examination is remarkable for psychomotor retardation, frequent tearfulness, depressed mood, and suicidal ideation.  Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient is experiencing a major depressive episode.  However, her history—a distinct period of aggressive mood with excessive energy; decreased need for sleep; increased goal-directed, risky behaviors (eg, personal business venture); and grandiosity severe enough to require hospitalization—is characteristic of a manic episode.  Therefore, she meets the criteria for bipolar I disorder.

Bipolar disorder has different phases (acute mania, acute bipolar depression, maintenance).  Although a wide range of options for the management of bipolar disorder exists, in patients (such as this one) with acute bipolar depression, some second-generation antipsychotics (SGAs) and mood stabilizers are commonly used due to superiority.

  • Select SGAs (eg, quetiapine, lurasidone) are often used because of simple dosing and comparative tolerability.

  • Mood stabilizers (eg, lithium, lamotrigine) are also effective, although the slow, stepwise increases that are necessary with lamotrigine often require augmentation therapy with another mood stabilizer or antipsychotic.

Antidepressant monotherapy is avoided in patients with bipolar I disorder due to the risk for inducing mania.  Antidepressants can sometimes be used with antipsychotics (eg, olanzapine plus fluoxetine) or mood stabilizers to decrease the risk for an antidepressant-induced switch from depression to mania.

Once the acute episode is controlled, the preferred strategy is to continue medication indefinitely (ideally at the lowest dose based on effectiveness and tolerability) to prevent harmful mood episodes from reemerging.  Some SGAs and mood stabilizers can also be used for acute manic episodes, and different medications are more effective in different phases.  All these characteristics help guide the regimen used in the maintenance phase.

(Choices A, B, and F)  Antidepressants can be used to augment the effects of first-line treatment options for bipolar depression.  Compared to serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (eg, venlafaxine) and tricyclic antidepressants (eg, amitriptyline), the norepinephrine-dopamine reuptake inhibitor bupropion, followed by selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (eg, citalopram), appears to carry less risk for inducing a switch to mania.  However, the potential consequences of precipitating a switch to mania (eg, bankruptcy, divorce, incarceration) restrict unopposed antidepressant monotherapy in bipolar I disorder.

(Choice C)  Haloperidol is a first-generation antipsychotic that can be used in acute mania but not in acute bipolar depression.  It is also associated with extrapyramidal adverse effects due to its potent dopamine receptor D2 antagonism.

(Choice D)  Although a family history of medication response can guide pharmacotherapy, unopposed tricyclic antidepressant use (eg, imipramine) is contraindicated in bipolar I depression, given the risk for a switch to mania.

Educational objective:
Some second-generation antipsychotics (eg, quetiapine, lurasidone) are effective in the depressed phase of bipolar illness.  Antidepressant monotherapy should be avoided in patients with bipolar I disorder.

questionList.questionText: A 24-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to sudden-onset blurry vision.  She also describes intermittent numbness and tingling in the legs for the past several weeks.  The patient has been under stress at school and is struggling to complete assignments on time.  She is worried about her mother, who was recently diagnosed with breast cancer, and feels too distracted to concentrate.  The patient's medical history is significant for 2 episodes of urinary incontinence that occurred 8 months apart and 1 episode of unilateral blindness that occurred after breaking up with her boyfriend last year.  In each instance, her symptoms resolved spontaneously over several weeks without treatment.  The patient has no other medical or psychiatric history.  Brain MRI shows multifocal, white matter, hyperintense T2 lesions in the corpus callosum and periventricular area.  This patient is most likely to develop which of the following conditions?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient's history of >2 clinically distinct episodes of CNS dysfunction with resolution and hyperintense lesions on MRI is consistent with multiple sclerosis (MS).  MS typically occurs in women age 15-50, is the most common autoimmune inflammatory demyelinating disease, and is characterized by a relapsing-remitting course of CNS dysfunction (eg, monocular blindness due to optic neuritis, motor and sensory loss/paresthesia below the level of the lesion, incontinence).  Relapses of MS may be more common after stressful life events.

Depression has been found in up to two-thirds of patients with MS and is the most common psychiatric complication.  Depression can occur at any time and is likely caused by a combination of factors, including inflammatory changes in the brain, immune system changes, and psychological reactions to neurological deficits and the challenges of living with MS.  Depression in MS is commonly underdiagnosed and undertreated.  Appropriate treatment, including psychotherapy and antidepressants, can alleviate suffering and improve quality of life.

(Choices A and G)  Conversion disorder, or functional neurological symptom disorder, is characterized by neurological symptoms (eg, weakness, abnormal movements, nonepileptic seizures) that are inconsistent with a neurological disease.  Somatic symptom disorder is characterized by excessive preoccupation with one or more unexplained somatic symptoms.  This patient's symptoms are due to a known neurological disease.  Patients with MS are not at increased risk of developing these disorders.

(Choice B)  Although cognitive impairment (eg, impaired attention, short-term memory, speed of information processing, executive function) is common in MS, frank dementia is not.  Cognitive impairment in MS is exacerbated by untreated depression.

(Choices D and E)  Although patients with MS commonly experience anxiety related to their illness, they are not at increased risk of developing generalized anxiety or panic attacks.

(Choice F)  Psychosis may be a complication of high-dose glucocorticoids used to treat MS but is not a common complication of the disease itself.

Educational objective:
Multiple sclerosis is frequently associated with depression.  Treatment, which includes psychotherapy and antidepressants, can alleviate suffering and improve quality of life.

questionList.questionText: A 72-year-old woman with breast cancer comes to the office for follow-up accompanied by her daughter.  The patient has undergone surgery and completed chemotherapy over the last 7 months; she was informed at her appointment last month that her cancer was in remission.  The daughter says that "despite the news of remission, Mother isn't any happier.  She eats very little, does not sleep more than 2 or 3 hours at a time, and cries frequently.  She also doesn't seem to enjoy visits from the family, reading, or watching her favorite television programs."  The patient says, "Wouldn't anyone who has been through this be depressed?"  She reports that her energy is still low following chemotherapy but that she is not in any pain.  She has stopped reading as she has difficulty concentrating and remembering.  The patient has lost 4.5 kg (10 lb) since her appointment a month ago.  She has no suicidal thoughts.  There are no changes on physical examination, and her laboratory results remain stable.  In addition to providing support, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient's history of depressed mood, anhedonia (inability to enjoy normally pleasurable activities), sleep difficulty, appetite disturbance, low energy, and impaired concentration meet the criteria for major depressive disorder (MDD).  The SIGECAPS mnemonic can assist in recall of the core signs and symptoms of MDD.  Diagnosis requires ≥5 of 9 symptoms for at least 2 weeks; one of these symptoms must be anhedonia or depressed mood.

Although some depressive symptoms in cancer patients are common, the development of major depressive disorder should not be normalized and considered an "expected" reaction (Choice C).  Untreated depression in medically ill patients causes reduced quality of life and additional anguish for families, and can negatively impact treatment adherence and medical management.  Treatment options include pharmacotherapy and/or psychotherapy.  Antidepressants are indicated for cancer patients with major depression and are safe and effective in this setting.

(Choices A, B, and G)  Encouraging the patient to express her feelings to her family, increase interaction with her family, and/or engage with a cancer support group may be beneficial adjunctive strategies to address her depression but alone are not adequate.  Support groups can be particularly important for cancer patients and family members who are distressed but are not a substitute for treating major depression.

(Choices E and F)  It is inappropriate to monitor the patient without intervention or reassure her that the symptoms will gradually improve now that she has completed chemotherapy.  Although chemotherapy side effects can overlap with neurovegetative features of depression (eg, fatigue, insomnia, weight loss), this patient's nonsomatic symptoms of depression (eg, pervasive and persistent sadness, anhedonia, tearfulness) are concerning for major depression.

Educational objective:
Medically ill patients who develop comorbid depression can benefit from treatment with antidepressant medications and psychotherapy to improve their quality of life.

questionList.questionText: A 24-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her boyfriend due to her behavior for the past week.  The boyfriend states that she has been unusually reactive to situations, frequently becoming angry or upset.  The patient abruptly quit her job as a congressional aide a few days ago, saying, "My boss was trying to sabotage me because she's jealous of my intellect.  The job was beneath me anyway.  The time has come for me to run for public office myself."  She has been organizing her campaign since quitting and calling potential donors at all hours of the day.  The patient yells at her boyfriend for bringing her to the hospital; a few minutes later, she hugs him and tearfully says, "I can't imagine my life without you."  She rarely drinks alcohol and does not use recreational substances.  The patient has no history of psychiatric or medical illness.  On mental status examination, she is easily agitated and cannot be redirected, jumping from one topic to another.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Manic episode

Clinical
features

  • ≥1 week of elevated or irritable mood & increased energy/activity
  • ≥3 of the following symptoms (4 if mood is irritable only) (DIGFAST mnemonic):
    • Distractibility
    • Impulsivity/indiscretion, risky behavior
    • Grandiosity
    • Flight of ideas/racing thoughts
    • Increased activity/psychomotor agitation
    • Decreased need for sleep
    • Talkativeness/pressured speech

Severity

  • Impaired psychosocial function
  • May have psychotic features (hallucinations, delusions)
  • May require hospitalization

This patient's weeklong history of abrupt behavior change is characterized by the following:

  • Irritable mood
  • Increased activity (calling political donors at all hours)
  • Impulsivity (quitting job)
  • Pressured speech (inability to be redirected)
  • Flight of ideas (jumping from one topic to another)

These changes are consistent with a manic episode of bipolar I disorder.

In addition to marked mood symptoms, during a manic episode, patients may exhibit psychotic features, which must be differentiated from primary psychotic disorders.  Delusions in mania often involve grandiose themes in which patients believe that they have special abilities or powers or are extraordinarily talented (eg, running for public office) or that others are jealous of them.  In contrast to primary psychotic disorders, delusions in bipolar disorder are present only during the active mood episode.

The mood episode at the onset of bipolar disorder may be manic (as in this patient), hypomanic, depressed, or mixed.  At least one manic episode is required to diagnose bipolar I disorder.  A history of depressive episodes is not required for the diagnosis, although most patients experience both manic and depressive episodes over the course of their lifetimes.

(Choices B and E)  Labile moods (eg, rapid shifts from anger to tears), impulsivity, unstable relationships, and chronic irritability are common in borderline personality disorder.  Grandiosity, desire for powerful positions, belief in one's specialness, and claims of other's jealousy are consistent with narcissistic personality disorder.  However, personality disorders involve patterns of long-standing behaviors.  This patient's symptoms are related to an active period of acute illness and represent a distinct change from baseline, findings more consistent with bipolar disorder.

(Choice C)  Brief psychotic disorder is characterized by psychotic symptoms (eg, delusions, hallucinations) for >1 day and ≤1 month.  However, brief psychotic disorder does not explain this patient's irritability, increased activity, impulsivity, pressured speech, and flight of ideas that are more consistent with bipolar mania.

(Choice D)  Delusional disorder involves one or more delusions lasting ≥1 months.  However, functioning and behavior generally remain intact at baseline.  The presence of delusions with a significant mood change makes bipolar mania more likely.

Educational objective:
Patients with ≥1 manic episodes are diagnosed with bipolar I disorder.  Depressive episodes are not required for the diagnosis but are common.  Manic episodes may include psychotic symptoms, often with grandiose themes.

questionList.questionText: A 27-year-old man comes to the office for postdischarge follow-up of a recent psychiatric hospitalization for a depressive episode with suicidal ideation.  The patient's depressive episode remitted with intensive inpatient psychotherapy and the initiation of a new medication regimen 1 month ago.  The patient has been home for a week and is feeling well.  He has a history of migraine headaches, bipolar disorder, and tobacco use disorder.  Family history is significant for major depressive disorder in his father.  Temperature is 37.5 C (99.5 F), blood pressure is 110/75 mm Hg, pulse is 72/min, and respirations are 14/min.  Examination is significant for a maculopapular rash over the patient's left scapula.  The patient is unaware of the rash, and discharge paperwork from the previous week does not document any rash.  Which of the following medications is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questionList.explanationText:
The anticonvulsant lamotrigine is used as a mood stabilizer in bipolar disorder and is often used specifically to target bipolar depression.  One of the most significant side effects of lamotrigine is a drug rash, a mild form of which occurs in up to 10% of those treated.  The more severe mucocutaneous rashes of Stevens-Johnson syndrome (<10% body surface area skin detachment) and toxic epidermal necrolysis (>30% detachment) occur at a rate of 0.1% (10%-30% detachment is known as Stevens-Johnson syndrome/toxic epidermal necrolysis overlap).

Because of the challenge of predicting the eventual severity of lamotrigine-induced rash at the outset, lamotrigine should be discontinued at the first sign of rash and substituted with another agent.  Most cases of lamotrigine-induced rash develop within the first 2 months of therapy.  Risk of rash is greater in children and appears to be higher when coprescribed with valproate or when the dose is increased rapidly.

(Choices A and G)  Antidepressants such as the selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors escitalopram and sertraline should be used with caution in bipolar depression, given the limited evidence of benefit and the risk of mood-switching from depression to mania.  Neither escitalopram nor sertraline is associated with a significant risk of rash.

(Choices B, D, E, and F)  Haloperidol, lurasidone, olanzapine, and quetiapine are all antipsychotic medications that may be used in the treatment of bipolar disorder; however, none are associated with a clinically significant risk of rash.

Educational objective:
A mild rash may develop in up to 10% of those treated with lamotrigine, whereas life-threatening Stevens-Johnson syndrome or toxic epidermal necrolysis may occur in 0.1%.  Any occurrence of rash during the treatment of lamotrigine requires immediate discontinuation of the drug.

questionList.questionText: A 68-year-old man comes to the office due to headaches and unexplained weight loss.  The patient says, "Something is definitely wrong with my brain."  Over the past month, he has become convinced that he has brain cancer despite reassurance by another physician that his laboratory and brain MRI results are normal.  The patient reports low energy and little appetite for the last 3 months.  He stopped cooking when his wife died 6 months ago and has lost 9 kg (19.8 lb).  The patient also quit his volunteer job due to headaches and an inability to concentrate, explaining, "I no longer enjoy the work anyway."  Medical history includes hypertension and osteoarthritis.  Physical and neurologic examinations are unremarkable.  On mental status examination, the patient moves and speaks slowly with frequent pauses.  He says, "Cancer is my punishment for sins I committed as a young child."  He denies suicidal ideation but says, "It doesn't matter because I am dying of cancer anyway."  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
In the absence of underlying medical illness, this patient's weight loss, low energy, impaired concentration, loss of interest, guilt, and psychomotor retardation are most likely due to major depression.  His conviction that he has brain cancer despite normal test results and that cancer is punishment for sins he committed as a child represents a delusion that specifies the subtype as major depressive disorder with psychotic features.  In this severe subtype of unipolar major depression, the depressive episode is accompanied by delusions and/or hallucinations, typically with depressive themes (eg, deserving punishment, worthlessness, nihilism).

Identification of psychotic features is important because treatment for psychotic depression is different than that for nonpsychotic depression.  First-line treatment of major depressive disorder with psychotic features is combination pharmacotherapy with an antidepressant and antipsychotic or with electroconvulsive therapy.

(Choice A)  In delusional disorder, mood symptoms, if present, are brief and not a prominent part of the illness.  They would not explain this patient's severe depressive symptoms.

(Choices B and E)  Patients with illness anxiety disorder are excessively concerned about having a serious, undiagnosed general medical condition.  Somatic symptom disorder is characterized by excessive anxiety and thoughts about the seriousness of at least 1 somatic symptom.  Neither diagnosis explains this patient's severe depression, associated somatic delusions, and delusions of guilt.

(Choice D)  Although this patient's depression may have been triggered by his wife's death, his symptoms are severe and meet the criteria for major depressive disorder.  Patients with persistent complex bereavement disorder (also referred to as complicated grief) commonly have depressive symptoms, but their sadness centers on the loss of a loved one and is characterized by intense yearning for the deceased.  It would not explain this patient's pervasive depression and delusions.

Educational objective:
Major depressive disorder with psychotic features is a severe subtype of unipolar major depression.  It is characterized by an episode of major depression accompanied by delusions and/or hallucinations, typically with depressive themes.

questionList.questionText: A 43-year-old woman presents to the emergency department complaining of feeling "horrible."  She has not been sleeping through the night, has been losing weight, and has crying fits throughout the day.  These symptoms began about 3 months ago when she discovered that her husband was having an affair.  She feels betrayed and foolish for having failed to recognize it sooner.  She states that she has been doubting her abilities as a wife and mother.  She has also stopped participating in her weekly book club and has not returned phone calls from friends and family recently, preferring to keep to herself instead.  She says she "just can't take the embarrassment" and has been having frequent thoughts of suicide.  The patient has been drinking 2-3 glasses of wine to help her fall asleep at night and using marijuana several times a month.  She has no psychiatric history.  Physical examination is unremarkable.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Suicide assessment: ideation, intent & plan

Evaluate ideation

  • Wish to die, not wake up (passive)
  • Thoughts of killing self (active)
  • Frequency, duration, intensity, controllability

Evaluate intent 

  • Strength of intent to attempt suicide; ability to control impulsivity
  • Determine how close patient has come to acting on a plan (rehearsal, aborted attempts)

Evaluate plan

  • Specific details: method, time, place, access to means (eg, weapons, pills), preparations
    (eg, gathering pills, changing will)
  • Lethality of method
  • Likelihood of rescue

All patients presenting with depression should be carefully screened for suicidal risk, as this screen is critical in determining the appropriate treatment setting and frequency of follow-up care (Table).  This patient is having suicidal thoughts, but their content and intensity are unclear and there is no indication of whether she has a plan or intent to act on a plan.  Before a treatment plan and setting is decided, it is essential to assess whether she is considering acting on a specific suicide plan.

Hospitalization to maintain safety is indicated for patients with active suicidal ideation that includes a plan and intent to act (Choice A).  Patients with suicidal ideation but no specific plan or intent need intensive outpatient treatment, but not necessarily hospitalization (eg, treat the underlying disorder with medication and/or psychotherapy, increase the frequency of clinical contact, mobilize supports).

(Choice B)  Ruling out medical conditions (eg, hypothyroidism, vitamin deficiencies) is common practice in patients with a new episode of depression.  However, this patient's clear history of a stressor, lack of medical symptoms, and normal physical examination make a medical cause unlikely.  Furthermore, suicidality is a psychiatric emergency, and a risk assessment is the most immediate concern at this point.  Laboratory tests would not change immediate management.

(Choice C)  Assessing for drug use is important as many substances can cause or make depression worse.  This woman is likely using alcohol and marijuana to manage her depressive symptoms and should be counseled against this.  However, obtaining a urine drug screen would not affect immediate management.

(Choices E, F, and G)  These treatment recommendations may be appropriate, but suicide assessment and determination of the appropriate treatment setting take precedence.  The selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor sertraline is a first-line antidepressant.  Individual psychotherapy is useful in the treatment of mild to moderate depression with or without medications.  Couples counseling may be considered after the patient is stabilized.

Educational objective:
All depressed patients should be screened for suicidal ideation, intent, and plan.  Actively suicidal patients with intent and plan will often need to be hospitalized for stabilization and to maintain their safety.
